title: How to Make Mashed Potatoes

steps.headline: Put the potatoes into a large pot of water.
steps.description: Do not peel or cut the potatoes. Instead, scrub them clean first, then put them into a large pot. Fill the pot enough water until the water level is 1 inch (2.54 centimeters) above the potatoes. Keeping the potatoes whole (not peeled or cut) will prevent them from absorbing too much water. It will also help preserve their flavor and texture.

steps.headline: Add ½ tablespoon of salt and boil the potatoes until they are well done.
steps.description: Depending on the size of the potatoes, this can take as little as 30 minutes to as long as 45 to 50 minutes. The potatoes are done if you can easily pierce them with a sharp knife or fork.

steps.headline: Drain the potatoes, then peel them if desired.
steps.description: You can leave the skins on if you wish, or you can peel them off. To do this, simply hold a potato in a potholder, then use a paring knife to pull the skin off; it should peel off easily.

steps.headline: Heat the butter and milk separately.
steps.description: Heat the butter in one saucepan, and the milk in another. For extra flavor, add the remaining salt to the milk. You will be adding the butter first, then the milk. This will help improve the texture of the potatoes.

steps.headline: Mash the potatoes.
steps.description: You can do this using a potato masher directly in the pot you cooked them in. This will also help keep them warm and you won't have to clean as many dishes. If you find mashing them difficult, cut them into smaller pieces using a knife first.

steps.headline: Stir the butter into the potatoes using a rubber spatula or a wooden spoon.
steps.description: Keep stirring until the butter is mixed evenly throughout. Over time, it will get absorbed into the potatoes. When that happens, you are ready for the milk.

steps.headline: Add the milk after the butter is absorbed and stir.
steps.description: The potatoes will appear liquidy at first, but they will eventually soak in the milk. If you are concerned about this, however, you can pour in the milk a little bit at a time, and add more after the potatoes have finished absorbing it.

steps.headline: Taste the potatoes and make any adjustments if desired.
steps.description: At this point, you can add extra salt, pepper, and butter. For extra flavor, add 1 tablespoon of any of the following: chopped chives, fresh dill, garlic, paprika, fresh chopped parsley, fresh rosemary, or fresh thyme. If you choose to use dried dill, rosemary, or thyme, reduce the amount to 1 teaspoon; taste, and add more if needed.

steps.headline: Serve the potatoes.
steps.description: Transfer them to a serving dish, and serve them while they are still hot. If you have any leftovers, cover them, and store them in the fridge.

steps.headline: Peel and cut the potatoes, then put them into a large pot of water.
steps.description: Peel the potatoes first, then cut them into 1-inch (2.54 centimeters) cubes; this will help them cook faster. Cover the potatoes with water; make sure they are completely submerged.

steps.headline: Add 2 teaspoons of salt, then cook the potatoes until they are tender, about 20 to 25 minutes.
steps.description: Bring the water to a boil first, then reduce the heat to a simmer. Cook the potatoes until they are soft and easily pierced with a fork.

steps.headline: Drain the potatoes and leave them in the pot.
steps.description: This will help dry the potatoes and keep them warm.

steps.headline: Mash the potatoes using a potato masher.
steps.description: Don't worry about getting them perfectly smooth just yet. You will be adding butter, milk, and sour cream later on, which will help make them smoother.

steps.headline: Add the butter, sour cream, salt, pepper, and ¾ cup (180 milliliters) of the milk.
steps.description: Stir them in using a rubber spatula or a wooden spoon. Don't add in all of the milk just yet; you may not need it. The potatoes may appear too thin at first, but they will thicken up once they soak up the milk and butter. If the mashed potatoes don't seem thick enough for your liking, read How to Thicken Mashed Potatoes.

steps.headline: Taste the potatoes and make any necessary adjustments.
steps.description: At this point, you can add some more salt, pepper, or milk. You can also add 1 tablespoon of fresh herbs, such as chopped chives, or 1 teaspoon of dried herbs, such as dill.

steps.headline: Serve the potatoes.
steps.description: They taste great on their own or with some extra butter. Cover and refrigerate any leftovers.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 350°F (177°C).
Boil the potatoes until they are tender, then drain them.
steps.description: Peel and cut the potatoes into 1-inch (2.54 centimeters) cubes first, then put them into a large pot of water; the water should cover completely cover the potatoes. Cook the potatoes until they are done, about 15 to 20 minutes, then drain them.

steps.headline: Mash the potatoes.
steps.description: Put the potatoes back into the pot, and mash them with a potato masher. Don't worry about making them perfectly smooth just yet; they will become smoother once you add the milk and sour cream.

steps.headline: Add the sour cream, milk, butter, and 1 cup (100 grams) of shredded cheese.
steps.description: Continue mashing the potatoes until everything is evenly combined. Once the potatoes are soft, you can stir them with a rubber spatula or wooden spoon. The potatoes may look soupy at first, but they will eventually soak up the liquid and thicken up. Save the remaining ½ cup (50 grams) of cheese for later.

steps.headline: Add the onion, bacon, salt, and pepper, and stir again.
steps.description: You can cook your own bacon beforehand, or you can use the pre-cooked, crumbled kind that comes from a package. Stir the potatoes until everything is evenly combined and distributed.

steps.headline: Scoop the potatoes into a greased, 2-quart (2 liters) casserole dish and cover them with the remaining shredded cheese.
steps.description: Smooth the potatoes down first with a spatula; any peaks that are sticking up may get burned. Next, sprinkle the rest of the cheese over them. Do not stir the cheese in.

steps.headline: Bake the potatoes for 30 to 35 minutes.
steps.description: The potatoes are ready when the cheese is melted and the potatoes are heated through.

steps.headline: Serve the potatoes.
steps.description: Let the potatoes cool a little first, then serve them while they are still hot. Cover and refrigerate any leftovers.
